introduction.p: In 1899 Marie Fabry and Jean Perot in France built an interferometer which used multiple beams by coating the two sides partially with a highly reflecting material. They found that multiple reflections resulted in much narrower interference fringes than other interferometers. It is widely used for precision spectroscopy, and as a gas laser cavity, among other things.

A Fabry-Perot interferometer shown in essentially consists of two parallel plates of glass whose inner surfaces are polished to a very high degree of flatness, and then coated with a highly reflecting thin film of silver or aluminum or some similarly good reflector. The outer surface of these plates are ground to make a wedge shape so that light escaping the cavity between the plates does not reflect back in. The distance d between plates can vary from a few millimeters to a few centimeters. Rays of light from an extended source enter the space between the reflecting plates, and emerge on both sides after each reflection. The rays emerging on the opposite end to the side of entrance are focused on a screen.

The extended light source, such as a mercury lamp is placed at the focal plane of a converging lens \text{L}_1 so that the rays coming from a single point of the source emerge parallel on the other side of the lens at a particular angle of inclination. The transmitted rays from rays of same angle of inclination enter the space between the two partial reflectors. focus on the same point in the focal plane of lens \text{L}_2. For instance, the three rays A, B and C from the source point P shown in the figure converge at the same point Q on the screen. The rays from points on the light source in a circle that contains P meet in a circle on the screen. If the condition at Q is met for a constructive interference, we will see a bright ring, while if the condition there corresponds to a destructive interference, there will be a dark ring there. The interference pattern on the screen will have alternating bright and dark rings. The reflectivity r of the coating can be adjusted to sharpen the rings as illustrated in .

figure.caption: Calculated fringes for different reflectivities in a Fabry Perot interferometer: (a) r = 0.3, (b) r = 0.85, (c) r = 0.98.

subsection.title: Interference Condition in Fabry-Perot Interferometer
subsection.p:
In Fabry-Perot interfermoter, its an infinte collection of waves that interfere. When we have only two waves as in , we saw that the condition depended on phase difference \Delta_{12} between the two waves. There, we had concluded that if \Delta_{12} is an integral multiple of 2\pi, then we will have constructive interference.
\text{Fabry-Perot Constructive: }\ \ \Delta_{12}=2m\pi\ \ (m \text{ integer})
To figure out an expression of phase difference \Delta_{12}, we analyze the optical paths as we did in , of two succesive rays, shown as \text{R}_1 and \text{R}_1 in .

figure.caption: Geometry of Fabry-Perot for phase difference calculation between the successively transmitted wave. The phase difference comes from path difference of ABCDE and ABGF. Path ABCDE has two phase flipping reflections, one at B and the other at C, which make the net phase change due to reflection equal to 2\pi.

subsection.p:
To find an expression of \Delta_{12} we figure out the difference of optical path lengths of ABCDE and ABGF.
\Delta\text{OPL} = n (\text{BC} + \text{CD}) - n (\text{GF}).
Now, from \triangle\text{ABX}, we can see that
\text{AB} = \frac{d}{\cos\theta},\ \ \text{BX} = d\tan\theta.
Now, we note that BC, CD, and GF can be written using these since
\text{BC} = \text{CD} = \text{AB},\ \ \text{GF}=\text{EG}\sin\theta,\ \ \text{EG}=\text{BD}=2\text{BX}.
Therefore, we get the following for \Delta\text{OPL}
\Delta\text{OPL} \amp = n \left( \frac{2d}{\cos\theta} - 2d\sin\theta\tan\theta \right) \amp = n\; \frac{2d}{\cos\theta} \times \cos^2\theta = 2 n d\cos\theta.
Let \lambda be the wavelength in the medium of Fabry Perot. Now, we know that phase changes by 2\pi radians when OPL changes by one wavelength, therefore, the phase difference between the two successive paths will be
\Delta_{12} = 2\pi\times \frac{\Delta\text{OPL}}{\lambda} = 2\pi \times\frac{2 n d\cos\theta}{\lambda}.
Demanding this to be equal to 2m\pi with m integers for constructive and equal to m^\prime\pi with m^\prime odd integers we get the interference conditions. Multiplying both sides by \lambda/2\pi we will write them as follows.
\amp \text{Constructive: }\ \ 2 n d \cos\theta = m \lambda \ \ (m\ \text{ integer}) \amp \text{Destructive: }\ \ 2 n d \cos\theta = m^\prime \lambda \ \ (m^\prime\ \text{ odd})

It is interesting to note in these equations that higher order of interference, corresponds to smaller angle.
\cos\theta_m \lt \cos\theta_{m+1}\ \ \Longrightarrow\ \ \theta_{m} \gt \theta_{m+1}.

sidebyside.p: That is, higher order interference are more towards the center of the Fabry Perot patterns. Similarly, in the same order, higher wavelength will be towards the center.

figure.caption: Higher orders and/or longer wavelengths towards center.

subsection.title: Intensity of Trnasmitted Waves in Fabry Perot
subsection.p: A more complete understanding of the wave interference in Fabry Perot interferometer requires examining the actual electromagnetic waves as we did when we studied the Fresnel equations for reflection and transmission in . That work is a little bit beyond the scope of this book. Even so, it is important to discuss implications of the results since Fabry Perot is used in many applications.

Let R be the reflectance of the surfaces on the two sides of the cavity. Let I_t be the intensity transmitted and I_i the incident intensity. Let \Delta_{12} be the phase difference between two successive waves in direction \theta as given in Eq. . The, the transmittance can be shown to be
T \equiv \frac{I_t}{I_i} = \frac{1}{1 + F \sin^2(\Delta_{12}/2)},
where F is called the finesse coefficient or quality factor. Finesse coefficient is a function of the reflectance.
F = \frac{4R}{(1-R)^2}.
Since 0\le R \le 1.0, F is highly nonlinear. Typically, R is in the 0.90\text{ to } 0.98 range. That corresponds to F in range 360 \text{ to } 9,800. With large finesse in Eq. , transittance becomes highly sensitive to \Delta, giving sharp peaks when plotted against \Delta_{12} or \theta.

The maxima and minima of transmittance in Eq. will correspond to the constructive and destructive interference, respectively. Therefore, for a fixed F, you can immediately see that T will me maximum when \sin(\Delta_{12}/2)=0. This immediately says that constructive interference will occur when
\Delta_{12}/2 = n\pi,\ \ (n\ \text{ integer}),
which is the result we have before. Additioanlly, Eq. also tells us how the maxima wil lbe distributed.

sidebyside.p: show plots of the transmittance versus the phase difference for two values of reflectance, R=0.5 and R=0.8. You can see that peaks, which correspond the fringes, become narrower with increase in reflectance. It is not uncommon to find laser cavities R=0.9999.

subsection.p:
I didn't plot that high a value here since you will just see a vertical in these plots if you used such values. A similar plot will result if we plot at a fixed angle but for various frequencies. This type of plot will give intensities of various frequencies in the direction specified by \theta. To do that we will write \Delta_{12} in terms of frequency by using \lambda f = v = c/n. We will also set n=1 for air. This gives
\Delta_{12} = f \times \left( 4\pi d \cos\theta \right).

shows a plot of transmittance versus frequency for a fixed \theta. The peaks in this plot correspond to different values of constructive interference order. We can see this by setting the right side of Eq. with an index to f in the interference condition.
f_m \times \left( 4\pi d \cos\theta \right) = 2\pi m,
where m is an integer.

figure.caption: Transmittance versus frequency. Frequency is shown in multiples of \frac{c}{2d\cos\theta} since n=1; in a medium of refractive index n, it will be c/2nd\cos\theta. The point labeled m corresponds to f=m\times \frac{c}{2d\cos\theta}, where c is speed of light in vacuum. The value of m can be very large. For instance, with \theta=30^\circ and d=0.5\text{m}, for a frequency of 0.5\times 10^{14}\text{ Hz}, you will have m \sim 83,333 . Note that near normal \cos\theta\sim 1.0. In that case free spectral range in air = c/2d; in a medium of refractive index n, it will be c/2nd.

subsection.p: The peaks are called resonant frequencies of the cavity. The width of a peak is defined by the range of frequencies when transmittance is 0.5. This width is called full width at half maximum (FWHM). Between successive peask, say between f_m and f_{m+1}, there is low signal. This range is call free spectral range.

subsection.title: Applications of Fabry-Perot Interferometer
subsection.p: Fabry-Perot has been valuable tool for high-resolution spectroscopy. In spectroscopy, you are interested in separating light of different wavelengths (or equivalently, of different frequencies). If a source of light emits light of many frequencies, and you want to know how much of light in which frequency, you would use a spectroscope. A simple prism can also separate light light into component frequencies, but it is not as resolving as a high power Fabry-Perot instrument. In the next chapter we will study diffraction gratings, which can also achieve good resolution. But, it is hard to beat the resolving power of a Fabry-Perot instrument.

By looking at the properties that go into the interference condition in the Fabry-Perot interferometer, you can identify kinds of properties that you can use the interferometer for - it relates refractive index n of the medium, the length d of the cavity, and wavelength \lambda of light.
2\pi \times\frac{2 n d\cos\theta}{\lambda} = 2\pi m,\ \ (m\text{ integer})
Depending upon our particular purpose for using a Fabry-Perot interferometer, we may vary one of these parameters and study the change with a detector.

When the cavity plates are fixed to a definite separation d, the arrangement is also called an etalon. For fixed n and d, the interference condition will depend upon the wavelength. So, if light source consists of two wavelengths, say a red light of 650\text{ nm} and a blue light of 450\text{ nm}, two separate rings for each interference order m are illustrated in . Of course, to separate such a widely different wavelength, you don't need Fabry-Perot.

sidebyside.p: A famous high resolution use of Fabry-Perot took place in the separation of sodium yellow doublet of wavelengths 588.9950\text{ nm} and 589.5924\text{ nm}. You can see an image shown in of the screen of sodium doublet in an experiment by visiting Hyperphysics website. The two lines are repeated for different orders.

subsection.p:
An instrument used for resolving spectral lines is rated by its resolving power. It is proportional to the inverse of minimum separation in wavelengths \Delta\lambda_\text{min} that the instrument can resolve .
\text{Resolving Power } \propto\ \frac{1}{\Delta\lambda_\text{min}}.
To make resolving power a dimensionless quantity, we multiply the right side by average wavelength. Thus,
\text{Resolving Power } =\left| \frac{\lambda_\text{av}}{\Delta\lambda_\text{min}}\right|.
How do we tell if two nearby wavelengths are separated? This is the same type of question as we had when we were studying telescopes. There, the question was how to tell if we could tell whether there were two stars or one star on the CCD. A commonly used criteria, called Raleigh criterion is that if the maximum of peak of one will be at less than half-width from the other peak, then we cannot be sure there are two peaks.

Suppose, we have a light that is mixture of two wavelengths \lambda_1 and \lambda_2 \gt \lambda_1. When this light is sent through a Fabry-Perot, they form peaks at \lambda_1 and \lambda_2 with half-width at half maximum of each to be w_1 and w_2 respectively. Raleigh criterion says that to be resolvable, we must have
\lambda_2 \gt \lambda_1 + w_1\ \ \text{and}\ \ \lambda_1 \lt \lambda_2 - w_2.
If w_2 \ge w_1, then, we just need to check \lambda_1 \lt \lambda_2 - w_2. (a) illustrates the idea behind what we would consider barely separated by Raleigh criterion. Figure (b) is visibly separated as you can see the dip between the peaks.

figure.caption: The idea of resolvability by Raleigh criterion illustrated. The case (a) is at the Raleigh criterion and (b) is much better than Raleigh.

subsection.p:
We can use Eq. to cast the resolving power in terms of finesse coefficient F of the instrument. For nearly normal incidence, resolving power can be shown to be
\text{Resolving Power } = \left|\frac{\lambda_\text{av}}{\Delta\lambda_\text{min}} \right| = \left[\frac{\pi \sqrt{F}}{2}\right]\, \frac{2 n d}{\lambda_\text{av}},
where the quantity between brackets, viz. \pi \sqrt{F}/2 , is called finesse of the instrument. We will denote finesse by {\cal{F}}.
{\cal{F}} = \frac{\pi \sqrt{F}}{2} = \frac{\pi\sqrt{R}}{1-R}.
It is useful to put finesse and the resolving power in one place with the reflectance.
{\cal{F}} = \frac{\pi\sqrt{R}}{1-R} = \frac{1}{2nd}\,\frac{\lambda^2}{\Delta\lambda},
where I have omitted subscripts for simplicity. You can use this formula to find {\cal{F}} you need for the resolution of light required, which can then be used to find the minimum reflectance needed on the cavity mirrors.

In the next chapter you will study another device called the diffraction gratings which are also used for the separation of light of different wavelengths. It turns out that it is much harder to construct a diffraction grating with as high a resolving power as a Fabry-Perot interferometer. For instance, let n = 1, d = 1\text{ cm}, \lambda = 650\text{ nm}, and reflectance R = 0.98, then the resolving power would be 4.8 \times 10^6. To get this kind of resolving power from a diffraction grating (which will be discussed in the next chapter) that has slit separation of 1000\text{ nm}, you will need diffraction from 1,560,000\text{ slits}, or 1.56-meter wide diffraction grating!

exercise.title: Resolving Power Required in a Fabry Perot Instrument for Separating Sodium Yellow Doublet

statement.p: Sodium yellow doublet consists of wavlengths 0.5889950\,\mu\text{m} and 0.5895924\,\mu\text{m}. These lines are to be separated by a Fabry-Perot interferometer that has air as its medium and length of cavity is 1.0\text{ cm}. What is the minimum resolving power and finesse of a Fabry-Perot interferometer used to resolve these lines?

solution.p:
Resolving power we need is
\frac{\lambda_\text{av}}{|\Delta\lambda|} = \frac{0.5889950 + 0.5895924}{ 2(0.5895924 - 0.5889950 )} = 982.
The finesse can be obtained by equating this to {\cal{F}} \times 2nd/\lambda_\text{av}.
{\cal{F}} = 982 \times \frac{(0.5889950 + 0.5895924)\times 10^{-6}/2 }{ 2 \times 1.0\times 1.0\times 10^{-2}} = 0.03.

exercise.title: Minimum Wavelength Difference Resolvable in a Fabry-Perot Interferometer

statement.p: You have acquired a Fabry-Perot interferometer with the following specifications: d=2.0\text{ cm}, R=0.9, n=1.1. Find the minimum wavelength difference you can resolve near wavelength of \lambda=0.632\ \mu\text{m}.

hint.p: Use formula for resolving power. It helps to calculate finesse first.

solution.p:
The finesse of the instument is
{\cal{F}} = \frac{\pi\sqrt{R}}{1-R} = 29.8.
This means resolving power will be
{\cal{F}}\,\frac{2nd}{\lambda} = 29.8\,\frac{2\times 1.1\times 2.0\times 10^-2}{0.632\times 10^{-6}} = 2.1\times 10^{6}.
Now, we equate this to \lambda/\Delta\lambda and solve for \Delta\lambda.
\Delta\lambda_\text{min} = \frac{ 0.632\ \mu\text{m} }{2.1\times 10^{6}} = 3.16 \times 10^{-7}\ \mu\text{m}.

exercise.title: Width of Transmittance Peaks of a Fabry-Perot Interferometer

statement.p:
Show the width in phase difference \Delta_{12} at half the height of a peak of T\equiv I_t/I_i in the assumption of narrow peaks is
\frac{4}{\sqrt{F}}\text{ or } \frac{2(1-R)}{\sqrt{R}}.

hint.p: Set T=\frac{1}{2} for \Delta_{12}=2\pi m \pm \frac{w}{2} where w is the full width.

solution.p:
Recall that peaks of T occur at \Delta_{12}=2\pi m with m an integer. Let \Delta_{12} at half height around peak \Delta_{12}=2m\pi for some m be
\Delta_{12} = 2\pi m \pm \frac{w}{2},
where w is the full width. Setting T at these values to 1/2 we get the following condition.
\frac{1}{2} = \frac{1}{1+ F\sin^2\left(\pi m \pm \frac{w}{4} \right)}.
Rearraning we get
1+ F\sin^2\left(\pi m \pm \frac{w}{4} \right) = 2.
Now, we use cosine double angle formula and expanding the resulting cosine to change this to
1+\frac{F}{2} - \frac{F}{2}\cos(w/2) = 2.
Solving these we get
\cos(w/2) = 1 - \frac{2}{F}.
Since peaks in Fabry-Perot are usually ver narrow, we can expand cosine in Taylor series and keep only upto square term.
1-\frac{1}{2} (w/2)^2 = 1 - \frac{2}{F}.
Therefore,
w = \frac{4}{\sqrt{F}}.
Replacing F by 4R/(1-R)^2, we get
w = \frac{2(1-R)}{\sqrt{R}}.

exercise.title: Reflectivity of Mirrors of Fabry-Perot Cavity Required to Separate Mercury Yellow-Orange Doublet

statement.p: What should be the reflectivity of the Fabry-Perot etalon so that the yellow-orange doublet of mercury, which correspond to wavelengths 576.959\text{ nm} and 579.065\text{ nm}, are just resolvable by Raleight criterion in m=100 order?

hint.p: Set the difference in wavelengths to equal half width of peaks.

solution.p:
The resolving of two wavelengths will occur if the peaks of constructive interference corresponding to the two wavelengths fall outside of half-width of the peaks. This give the condition of resolution in the m^\text{th} order to be
\dfrac{\Delta \lambda}{\lambda_{\textrm{ave}}} = \dfrac{1-R}{m\pi\sqrt{R}},
where I used 2 n d \cos\theta = m \lambda for the m^\text{th} order. For the given lines we need the following R in m=100. \[ \dfrac{2.106}{578.012} = 0.00364352 = \dfrac{1-R}{100\pi\sqrt{R}}. \] Squaring both sides and rearranging we get \[ R^2 - 3.31 R + 1 = 0,\ \ \Longrightarrow\ \ R = 0.336. \]
